name: Dôn

attributes.attribute: once traced lineage in this fashion

sources: Dexter, Miriam Robbins. “Queen Medb, Female Autonomy in Ancient Ireland, and Irish Matrilineal Traditions.” In Proceedings of the Ninth Annual Ucla Indo-European Conference, edited by Karlene Jones-Bley, Angela Della Volpe, Miriam Robbins Dexter, and Martin E. Huld, 95–122. Washington, D.C.: Institute for the Study of Man, 1998.
Dexter, Miriam Robbins. Whence the Goddesses: A Sourcebook. New York: Pergamon Press, 1990. Pp. 42-46.
MacCulloch, J. A. The Religion of the Ancient Celts. London: Constable, 1911, 103.
Rhys, John. The Welsh People. London: T. Fisher Unwin, 1906, 37.
Spence, Lewis. The Minor Traditions of British Mythology. (New York: Benjamin Blom, Inc., 1972), 21.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: The Welsh goddess known as Dôn lends her name to the gods of Wales, who are called the Children of Dôn, akin to Ireland's Tuatha Dé Danann, the tribe of the goddess Danu. Despite being relatively unknown, Dôn is the mother of many children who feature prominently in Welsh mythology. Her offspring include Arianrhod, a virgin mother who becomes a footstool for Dôn's brother King Math, and four sons, each with important social roles. Among them are Gwydion the Bard, Govannon the Smith, Amaetheon the farmer, and Gilfaethwy the irreverent trickster. Although Dôn herself is an enigma, her name links her to numerous other divinities associated with fertility, including Danu and Anu in Ireland and a hypothesized Danu of the continent, a goddess of watercourses who has given her name to the Danube River. Furthermore, Welsh waterways like Trydonwy and Dyfrdonwy echo Dôn's name, while one of the Three Wells in the ocean is also called Dyfrdonwy. It is also possible that Dôn and Domnu, goddess of the ocean and ancestral mother of the Fomorians, an early Celtic people in Ireland, are one and the same. Alternatively, some tales depict Danu's children as also being the children of Brigit, leading to the possibility that all three of these goddesses represent one divine force, an original single goddess that has been confused throughout time by storytellers. Like the Tuatha Dé Danann, the Children of Dôn take their mother's name, with no mention of their father. As a result, their inheritance was matrilineal, meaning it was traced through the maternal line (see Matriliny). Interestingly, Dôn's descendants continue to follow this tradition. When Dôn's brother, Math, died, he was succeeded not by his own son, but by his nephew, Gwydion - Dôn's son; Gwydion, in turn, was succeeded by his sister Arianrhod's son, Lleu Llaw Gyffes. The matrilineal successions of these deities have given rise to the theory that they originated from a time when humans also traced their ancestry through the maternal line. Some scholars propose that matriliny might have been a pre-Celtic tradition that survived into Celtic times, when native women bore children to the invading Celts. According to this hypothesis, the stories describe the "inheritance" of their mothers' lands by the children of half-Celtic descent. Others use the consistency of matrilineal descent in Celtic myth from a variety of regions to argue that the Celts themselves once traced their lineage in this way.
